tools.result: "[\"Directing edits to correct mutated sequences was first proposed and demonstrated in 1995.[267] This initial work used synthetic RNA antisense oligonucleotides complementary to a pre-mature stop codon mutation in a dystrophin sequence to activate A-to-I editing of the stop codon to a read through codon in a model xenopus cell system.[267] While this also led to nearby inadvertent A-to-I transitions, A to I (read as G) transitions can correct all three stop codons, but cannot create a stop codon. Therefore, the changes led >25% correction of the targeted stop codon with read through to a downstream luciferase reporter sequence. Follow on work by Rosenthal achieved editing of mutated mRNA sequence in mammalian cell culture by directing an oligonucleotide linked to a cytidine deaminase to corr\",\"Directing edits to correct mutated sequences was first proposed and demonstrated in 1995.[267] This initial work used synthetic RNA antisense oligonucleotides complementary to a pre-mature stop codon mutation in a dystrophin sequence to activate A-to-I editing of the stop codon to a read through codon in a model xenopus cell system.[267] While this also led to nearby inadvertent A-to-I transitions, A to I (read as G) transitions can correct all three stop codons, but cannot create a stop codon. Therefore, the changes led >25% correction of the targeted stop codon with read through to a downstream luciferase reporter sequence. Follow on work by Rosenthal achieved editing of mutated mRNA sequence in mammalian cell culture by directing an oligonucleotide linked to a cytidine deaminase to corr\"]"

reasoning: The URL returns HTTP 200 - it's live. Now let me assess the citation accuracy by reviewing the claim and reference:

tools.result: "\"Directing edits to correct mutated sequences was first proposed and demonstrated in 1995.[267] This initial work used synthetic RNA antisense oligonucleotides complementary to a pre-mature stop codon mutation in a dystrophin sequence to activate A-to-I editing of the stop codon to a read through codon in a model xenopus cell system.[267] While this also led to nearby inadvertent A-to-I transitions, A to I (read as G) transitions can correct all three stop codons, but cannot create a stop codon. Therefore, the changes led >25% correction of the targeted stop codon with read through to a downstream luciferase reporter sequence. Follow on work by Rosenthal achieved editing of mutated mRNA sequence in mammalian cell culture by directing an oligonucleotide linked to a cytidine deaminase to correct a mutated cystic fibrosis sequence.[268] More recently, CRISPR-Cas13 fused to deaminases has been employed to direct mRNA editing.[269]\""

input.notes: The oldest reference in the CRISPR gene editing Wikipedia article is Woolf et al. (August 1995), 'Toward the therapeutic editing of mutated RNA sequences', published in PNAS 92(18):8298-8302. The reference ID is cite_note-RNA_editing_Woolf_1995-267. The source URL (PMC41144) returned HTTP 200 and is live. The citation supports the claim that 'directing edits to correct mutated sequences was first proposed and demonstrated in 1995' - which directly matches the paper's content about using RNA oligonucleotides to direct A-to-I editing of a premature stop codon mutation, confirming the citation is accurate. Note: Several references had numbers like 1801, 1832 etc. in their text, but these were DOI numbers and article page numbers, not publication years. The actual publication years were identified by extracting dates from the author-date citation format (e.g., 'Author (Month YEAR)').
